lines.text: Look! Live children!
Why do they call us live children?
I don't know.
You're live children, aren't you?
Well, of course we're alive. Aren't you alive?
Not yet. We're waiting to be born.
Look how funny they dress.
I was thinking the same thing about you.
What are those things on your feet?
They're my shoes. They're for protecting your feet from thorns and stones and the cold.
It's all very confusing, but I expect we'll understand it when we're born.
Why don't you get born?
We will, but we have to wait our turn. Is it nice on Earth?
Yeah, it's all right.
It's beautiful!
Your daddy got up at daybreak and made a cage for your bird. Do you like it?
Oh, Tyltyl, look! My bird, look what's happened to it! It's blue! It's the blue bird!
The blue bird?
We looked everywhere for it, and all the time it was right here!
Angela! You're up! You're walking!
Yes, Mother. Look, it's Mytyl's bird. She's given it to me.
It's the blue bird, Mrs. Berlingot.
Oh, Angela, I can't believe it! It's a miracle. I must go and tell your father!
Can I hold it now, Mytyl? Oh, it's so soft and warm! Will - Oh, Mytyl, it's gone! Oh, it got away!
Don't cry. We'll find it again.
Oh no, we can't. We can't ever.
Oh yes, we can, Angela. I'm sure of it. Because now, we know where to look for it, don't we?
Mytyl, Mytyl! Oh, you're Mytyl! And Tyltyl!
How do you know our names?
That's not very surprising. When I'm born, I'm going to be your little sister.
Our little sister! Oh, when?
I don't know just when. In a year or so.
Oh, that's wonderful!
Yes. In a way.
In a way? There will be three of us! We'll have lots of fun together!
Not for very long.
Why not?
I'll only be with you a short while.
And then you're going away?
Yes.
It's hardly worthwhile you coming at all, is it?
It would seem so, but we can't pick and choose.
Angela! Angela, close that window! You know better than that!
But it's Mytyl. She's got a bird.
Yes, yes, but you're sick enough, dear, without catching your death of cold. Now close the window.
Oh, Mother, I've always wanted a bird like this. Please ask her to give it to me.
That one, she'd never give anybody anything.
Angela Berlingot wanted me to give it to her.
Well, why didn't you? She needs something to cheer her up. Poor child, sick in bed all winter.
It's not my fault she's sick.
It's your fault you're selfish.
You have so much that she hasn't, Mytyl.
What do I have?
Health, for one thing. You can run around and play.
Oh, that isn't anything.
I wouldn't like to stay in bed all day.
I wouldn't mind.
Mummy, why do we have to be so poor all the time?
Poor? Us?
Well, we are. We can't even have a party for Christmas.
You have a roof over your head, haven't you? And warm clothes.
These old things?
And plenty to eat.
Nothing I like! Nothing good! Not like those rich children have. Cakes, candies, dolls to play with, pretty dresses - everything! I have nothing.
You have plenty.
What do I have?
A father who works hard for you.
And a mother who cooks and cleans and mends.
Oh Daddy, I don't want you to go.
I have to go, darling.
Why do they have to have war? What makes war, anyway?
The same things that make trouble everywhere. Greed. Selfishness. Those who aren't content with what they have.
But you're not like that, Daddy. Why should you have to go?
That's what's wrong about it, Mytyl. You can't be unhappy inside yourself without making others unhappy, too.
Mummy, I'm sorry for the way I behaved at supper.
That's what you always say, Mytyl, that you're sorry. But the next day you do the same thing right over again.
I know I do, and I don't know why.
Well, you must find out why. Otherwise you'll always be unhappy and discontent. You don't want that, do you? You want to be happy, don't you?
Yes, Mummy. Like you. You're happy all the time, aren't you?
Nearly all the time, dear.
Don't worry, Mummy. Daddy will be back.
Who are you?
Haven't you got eyes? Can't you see? I'm Berylune!
Berylune?
Yes, Berylune! The fairy! Hurry now, quick! Get into your clothes and be off! You've got to find the blue bird!
The blue bird?
Yes, the bird that's blue! The blue bird!
But why? Why should we find it?
You want to be happy, don't you?
Of course, but what do I want with an old blue bird?
What a stupid girl you are! Don't you know that the blue bird means happiness?
Can she talk, too?
Well, naturally. If the dog can.
Oh, Tylette, I'm so glad! We've got to find the blue bird!
The blue bird?
I'll come! I'll help you!
You'll come too, won't you, Tylette?
Why not? It might be amusing.
I don't like the way she said that.
Why, Tylo!
We shouldn't take Tylette along. She's treacherous.
What silly children you are not to know this lady! You've seen her hundreds of times. This is Light. Light, may I present Mytyl and Tyltyl.
How do you do, Light?
How do you do?
There's no need to be formal. We're old friends. Where would you like to go? I shall be your guide.
We're not sure where to go.
Why don't you use your head? Hasn't it occurred to you that the blue bird might be hiding in the Past?
But where is the Past? Do you know the way?
Why, of course. The Past is right behind us.
I know we've never been friends, but now we've got to work together. We can't allow the children to go through with this.
Why not? Why can't we?
Don't you see? We're free now! If they succeed and find the blue bird, we'll have to go back to what we were. Animals! Dumb slaves to man!
That's the way I like it! Man is the master, and we must obey him.
I always knew you were a fool.
If they want to look for a blue bird or a pink owl, I'm gonna help them!
Somebody must be thinking of us. I feel quite strong. I think we're going to have visitors. They seem to be coming near.
Maybe now I can finish my carving. I've been at this one for nearly a whole year.
That's because we're so seldom awake.
Granny! Grandpa!
It's the children! Give us a hug, dears, a big one this time.
It's been months and months since you last remembered us.
The last time was Easter morning. The church bells were ringing.
Easter? Oh, we didn't go out that day. We both had very bad colds.
But you thought of us.
Yes, we missed you.
Every time you think of us, we wake up and see you again.
But we thought you were dead.
No, dear. Only when we're forgotten.
Why don't you go to the Land of Luxury? There's plenty to eat there. Everything you could think of.
Do you think we'd find the blue bird there?
No, dear. I don't.
Why not? They'll have everything they want there. Where would be a better place to look for the blue bird?
We might find the blue bird there.
Very well. Go there if you want.
How do we get to the Land of Luxury?
It's very easy. We take the first side road.
Will you be waiting for us?
Yes, dear, just beyond. But don't stay too long. It's never wise to spend too much time in the Land of Luxury.
Why didn't you think to get each of them a pony? Then they'd have nothing to quarrel over!
Why didn't you? Well, don't stand there gaping! Go and get another pony!
Yes, sir.
All right, you can have this old pony! They'll get me a better one!
Oh, no! You keep this one, and I'll take the better one!
I'll get there first!
Oh no, you won't!
There just seems to be no satisfying them.
If you ask me, they're spoiled.
Nobody here is kind. Not really kind. Not like Mommy and Daddy. I wouldn't trade them for all the Mr. and Mrs. Luxuries in the world!
Even if they are poor.
Mommy and Daddy aren't poor. They just haven't any money. There's a difference.
Let's say we get out of here. Where's Tyltyl?
I don't know. We're not speaking.
What? Not speaking? What's this place doing to us all? We've got to get out of here.
Well, I guess there are enough of us here.
Then speak up!
The children of the woodcutter, your mortal enemy, are on their way here, looking for the blue bird.
The blue bird?
I've put as many obstacles in their way as I can, but now it's up to you.
What do you want us to do?
Frighten them! Terrify them! Put the fear of the devil into them! They'll forget what they came for and go back where they belong. Oak, I rely upon you.
Oh, this is going to be jolly fun!
Jolly fun? Are you all daft? Didn't you hear what she said? They're looking for the blue bird. What good would it do to frighten them? They'll only come back again and again. We must destroy them!
Lightning struck, and the whole forest went up in flames.
Lightning and Fire are my stepbrothers. They're very wicked.
We nearly got burned up.
Tylette did get burned up.
She got what she deserved.
Don't say that, Tylo! Poor Tylette.
There, there, dear. Don't be unhappy. What about the blue bird?
We didn't see one, not one. We didn't have time to look.
If you ask me, there is no such bird.
Oh, there is, Tylo. There must be!
You haven't looked everywhere. The blue bird may be in the Future.
There's something wrong with these children. They must have eaten something last night that disagreed with them.
Well, they look all right to me.
But they've been talking such nonsense! About seeing their grandparents!
But we did, Daddy! We really did!
But we're home now.
And we missed you so!
You mean you're going to miss me when I go to war.
Oh. I had forgotten about that.
